case_name: London Rubber Co., Ltd. v. Durex Products Inc.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 26 of 1961 was filed in the Supreme Court from the judgment and order dated July 10, 1958 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original No. 41 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 26 of 1961. From the judgment and order dated July 10, 1958 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original No. 41 of 1955.

facts.text: The judgment of the Supreme Court was delivered on March 4, 1963 by MUDHOLKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. March 4. The judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR J.-In. this appeal by a certificate granted by the High Court of Calcutta under Art. 133  1   c  of the Constitution,

facts.text: Durex Products Inc., of New York City, U.S.A. made an application before the Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks on May 28, 1946 for registering the mark Durex used on contraceptive devices.

anchor.surface_text: the Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks, Calcutta, was right in admitting to registration the trade mark Durex which respondent No. 1 claims to own and is using on the packing of the companytraceptives manufactured and marketed by it. The Durex Products Inc., of New York City, U. S. A. made an application before the Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks on May 28, 1946 for registering the mark Durex used by it on companytraceptive devices including prophylactic sheaths or companydrums, vaginal diaphragms, instruments for inserting diaphragms and models for demonstrating insertion of diaphragms, vaginal jellies, applicators for vaginal jellies and surgical lubricating jellies.

facts.text: London Rubber Co., Ltd. lodged opposition to the registration on March 29, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Its claim is disputed by the London Rubber Co., Ltd., London, the appellant before us by lodging an opposition to the registration on March 29, 1951. The appellant claims to be well-established manu- facturer of surgical rubber goods and proprietor in India of the trade mark Durex which it has been using in India since the year 1932 i. e., from the year in which it was registered in the United Kingdom.

facts.text: Appellant has been using the trade mark Durex in India since 1932.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claims to be well-established manu- facturer of surgical rubber goods and proprietor in India of the trade mark Durex which it has been using in India since the year 1932 i. e., from the year in which it was registered in the United Kingdom.

facts.text: Appellant applied for registration of Durex in clause X on December 23, 1946, granted on July 11, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On December 23, 1946 the appellant applied for registration of the word Durex in clause X which application was granted on July 11, 1951. Thereafter, on July 24, 1954 the registration was renewed for a period of 15 years as from December 23, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant's registration of Durex was renewed on July 24, 1954 for 15 years from December 23, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on July 24, 1954 the registration was renewed for a period of 15 years as from December 23, 1953. The respondent No. 1s application as well as the appellants opposition came up before the Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks who, by order dated December 31, 1954, overruled the objection and admitted the mark Durex to registration as sought by the respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Deputy Registrar overruled opposition and admitted Durex to registration on December 31, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent No. 1s application as well as the appellants opposition came up before the Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks who, by order dated December 31, 1954, overruled the objection and admitted the mark Durex to registration as sought by the respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Appeal to Calcutta High Court under s.76 of Trade Marks Act, 1949 was dismissed on March 9, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order an appeal was preferred before the High Court of Calcutta under s. 76 of the Trade Marks Act, 1949 which was dismissed -by a Division Bench of that Court on March 9, 1959 After obtaining a certificate of fitness from the High Court the appellant has companye up before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In. this appeal by a certificate granted by the High Court of Calcutta under Art. 133  1   c  of the Constitution, the question which arises for companysideration is whether the Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks, Calcutta, was right in admitting to registration the trade mark Durex which respondent No. 1 claims to own and is using on the packing of the companytraceptives manufactured and marketed by it.

facts.text: Respondent claims honest concurrent use of Durex from 1928.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents mark though it is identical with that of the appellants and though the appellants mark was number registered at the date of the respondents applicaton upon the ground of honest companycurrent use of the mark by the respondent from the year 1928 and also on the ground that there are other special circumstances.

facts.text: Deputy Registrar admitted mark under s.10(2) due to honest concurrent use and special circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant the main companytention urged by Mr. Pathak is that as the marks are identical, deception of various purchasers was inevitable and that, therefore, registration had to be refused under s. 8  a  of -the Act.

facts.text: Appellant claims marks are identical, leading to inevitable deception.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant the main companytention urged by Mr. Pathak is that as the marks are identical, deception of various purchasers was inevitable and that, therefore, registration had to be refused under s. 8  a  of -the Act. In admitting the mark to registration the Deputy Registrar was, according to him, in error in applying the provisions of s. 10  2  of the Act inasmuch as the provisions of 8  a  are number subject to those provisions.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld registration under s.10(2) for honest concurrent use.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we agree with the High Court and the Deputy Registrar that honest companycurrent use of the mark by the respondent for a companysiderable period has been established.

facts.text: Durex Products Inc. incorporated in January 1928 in New York.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany was incorporated in January, 1928 in New York.On 24 February, 1930 Durex ProductsInc. applied to the United States Patent Officefor the registration of the trade mark Durex and in that application it is expressly said by Flo- rence S. Goodwins affidavit that the use of the trade mark Durex upon the product is shown for the period beginning from March, 1928.

facts.text: Respondent applied for US registration of Durex on February 24, 1930, use from March 1928.

anchor.surface_text: On 24 February, 1930 Durex ProductsInc. applied to the United States Patent Officefor the registration of the trade mark Durex and in that application it is expressly said by Flo- rence S. Goodwins affidavit that the use of the trade mark Durex upon the product is shown for the period beginning from March, 1928.

facts.text: No instance of confusion between the marks throughout the period.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court, after observing that the burden was undoubtedly on the respondent to establish that there was numberreasonable probability of companyfusion, has held that that burden is discharged by the eloquent fact that throughout there has number been a single instance of companyfusion.

facts.text: Respondent's goods are contraceptives for women, requiring medical assistance; appellant's for men.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there is hardly any likelihood of companyfusion or deception here because the respondents goods are companyfined to companytraceptives for use by women which can only be used with medical assistance while the appellants companytraceptives arc essentially for men.

facts.text: High Court dismissed appeal on March 9, 1959 after accepting evidence of substantial use since 1930.

anchor.surface_text: P. B. Mukherji J., who was one of the Judges companystituting the Bench which heard the case has described that statement as dependable evidence on which he was prepared to rely and act.

facts.text: Florence S. Goodwin, President of Durex Products Inc., affirmed substantial business in India since 1930.

anchor.surface_text: One piece of evidence companysisted of an affidavit sworn by Florence S. Goodwin, who is the President of Durex Products Inc. There, among other things, she has stated Your deponent knows that Durex Products Incorporated has done a substantial business in India since 1930.

facts.text: Appellant concedes honest use but disputes concurrent use volume.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court Mr. S. Chaudhari who appeared for the present appellant companyceded that there was honest use in this case but there was numberconcurrent use within the meaning of s. 10  2 .

facts.text: Samples of respondent's contraceptives exported to India from 1928, substantial quantities thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, for introducing the goods to India samples were originally sent in the year 1928 or go but subsequent to that, the affidavit of Goodwin on -which reliance has been placed by the High Court and the Deputy Registrar, shows that substantial quantities of companytraceptives were exported to India.

facts.text: Diminution in volume during war due to import ban from dollar area, but considerable use before.

anchor.surface_text: There might have been a diminution in the volume of use during the war period because of a ban on imports of companytraceptives from the dollar area but that was only for a short time. But even before this ban was imposed the volume of use of the respondents mark in India was companysiderable.

facts.text: Word Durex is the name of the respondent company itself.

anchor.surface_text: In the first instance the word Durex is the name of the companypany itself. The companypany used its own name on its own product which every companypany should be entitled numbermally to use unless there be companyent reasons against it.

facts.text: Appellant's letter of October 27, 1949 admitted respondent's application for different goods.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Registrar, however, as already stated, resorted to the provisions of sub-s.  2  of s. 10 in admitting that mark to registration. We will quote whole of s. 10 as the provisions of sub-s.  1  as well as of sub-s.  3  were referred to in the argument before us along with the provisions of sub-s.  2 . Section 10 of the Act reads thus Save as provided in sub-section  2 , numbertrade mark shall be registered in respect of any goods or description of goods which is indentical with a trade mark belonging to proprietor and already on the respect of the same goods or description goods, or which so nearly resemble such trade mark as to be likely to deceive or cause companyfusion.

holdings.text: The provisions of sub-s. (2) of s. 10 are by way of an exception to the prohibitory provisions of the Trade Marks Act contained in s. 8(a) and s. 10(1), permitting registration despite identical marks.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the provisions of sub-s.  2  of s. 10 are by way of an exception to the prohibitory provisions of the Trade Marks Act. Those provisions are contained in s. 8  a  and s. 10  1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of s.10(2) is wide and independent, not limited as proviso to s.10(1); analogous to English ss.11-12; avoids absurd result of higher protection for unregistered marks; full legislative effect without narrowing.

holdings.text: Sub-s.(2) of s.10 applies irrespective of whether an identical or similar mark is already registered.

anchor.surface_text: The language of s. 8 a  is wide and though upon giving full effect to that language the provisions of s. 10 1  would, in some respects, overlap those of s. 8 a , there can be no justification for not giving full effect to the language used by the legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.10(2) not labelled proviso; wide language embraces registered/unregistered marks; s.10(3) also independent; distinguishes proper provisos like Art.286(2); English law supports discretion despite prohibition.

holdings.text: Honest concurrent use of the mark by the respondent for a considerable period has been established.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we agree with the High Court and the Deputy Registrar that honest concurrent use of the mark by the respondent for a considerable period has been established.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence including Goodwin affidavit shows substantial commercial business in India since 1930; accepted by lower courts; volume sufficient if commercial, no statutory minimum or hard rule required.

holdings.text: No hard and fast rule can be laid down regarding the volume of use for honest concurrent use under s.10(2); ordinarily commercial use is sufficient.

anchor.surface_text: No hard and fast rule can be laid down regarding the volume of use for the purposes of sub-s.  2  of s. 10. Ordinarily it would be sufficient if it is shown that there was a commercial use of the mark.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Depends on facts; business/commercial use required, not stray; small trader entitled if honest; agrees with High Court and Kerly; volume relevant but no express emphasis on large scale.

holdings.text: The 1st, 2nd and 4th circumstances (company name, long prior use, different goods/admission) are special circumstances justifying registration under s.10(2), but not the 3rd (socio-economic).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Special circumstances must connect to use of mark (per Kerly); 1st/2nd/4th peculiar to application; 3rd irrelevant as socio-economic not related to mark use; concurrent use alone sufficient.

holdings.text: There is no reasonable probability of confusion or deception.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No single instance of confusion over long concurrent use; burden discharged; goods differ (women/medical vs men); supports honest concurrent use and registration.

holdings.text: Deputy Registrar and High Court were right in admitting the mark Durex to registration under s.10(2).

anchor.surface_text: the question which arises for consideration is whether the Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks, Calcutta, was right in admitting to registration the trade mark Durex which respondent No. 1 claims to own and is using on the packing of the contraceptives

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.10(2) exception applies; honest concurrent use established; special circumstances support; no confusion; upholds lower courts.

Dunn 2 .

anchor.surface_text: In support of this companytention he has referred us to Ram Narain Sons Ltd., v. Assistant Commissioner of Sales Tax , . That was a case where this Court was companysidering the proviso to Art. 286 2 of the Constitution and the Court held that a proviso was meant only to lift the ban under Art. 286 2 and numberhing more.

precedents.case_name: Ram Narain Sons Ltd v Assistant Commissioner of Sales Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: a proviso to a provision only carves out an exception to the main provision
precedents.cited_holding: It is a cardinal rule of interpretation that a proviso to a particular provision of a statute only embraces the field which is companyered by the main provision. It carves out an exception to the main provision to which it has been enacted as a proviso and to numberother.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the provisions of sub-s. 2 of s. 10 are by way of an exception to the prohibitory provisions of the Trade Marks Act. Those provisions are companytained in s. 8 a and s. 10 1 . It has been held in Bass v. Nicholson 1 , that a trade mark is number necessarily entitled to protection because its use might deceive or cause companyfusion and, there- fore, s. 11 does number override s. 12 2 of the English Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: a trade mark is not necessarily disentitled to protection because its use might deceive; s11 does not override s12(2)

anchor.surface_text: In Kerly on Trade Marks, 8th edn. the position is stated thus It is number companyrect to companysider section II with. out any regard to the provisions of other sections of the Act. The general prohibition companytained in section 11 does number companyer the cases where the tribunal thinks fit to exercise the discretion companyferred by use under section 12 2 pp. 168-9 . In support of this statement of the law reliance is placed on Spillers Ltds Application 2 .

precedents.cited_proposition: construction of relation between ss11 and 12 of 1938 Act following 1905 Act cases; discretion under s12(2) takes case out of s11 prohibition

anchor.surface_text: In Halsburys Laws of England, Vol. 38, the legal position is stated thus at p. 543 The foregoing provision s. 11 does number override the statutory effect of honest companycurrent use and an objection under the foregoing provision may be disposed of if there is evidence that the mark has been honestly used without companyfusion resulting. In support of this statement reliance has been placed on Bass v. Nicholson Sons Ltd., 1 , as well as

anchor.surface_text: reliance has been placed on Bass v. Nicholson Sons Ltd., 1 , as well as Alexander Pierie Sons Ltd.s Application 2 , and Be Kidax Shirts Ltd.s Application 3 .
